meta.description: Complete CBT cognitive distortions library mapped to tarot archetypes

cognitive_distortions.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
cognitive_distortions.definition: Viewing situations in only two categories instead of on a continuum
cognitive_distortions.example: If I'm not perfect, I'm a total failure

card_meanings.The Tower: Represents sudden extremes, the shattering of rigid thinking
card_meanings.Two of Swords: Stuck between binary choices, unable to see nuance
card_meanings.Justice: Harsh self-judgment without mercy or middle ground

therapeutic_prompts: What evidence contradicts this extreme view?
Can you find the gray area between these extremes?
How would you advise a friend in this situation?
reframing_questions: Instead of perfect or failure, where do you fall on a 0-10 scale?
What's ONE thing you did well, even if everything wasn't perfect?
What would 'good enough' look like in this situation?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Practice accepting 'B+ work' on a low-stakes task this week

cognitive_distortions.name: Overgeneralization
cognitive_distortions.definition: Making broad interpretations from a single or few events
cognitive_distortions.example: I failed this test, I'm going to fail everything

card_meanings.The Hermit: Isolation based on one past experience
card_meanings.Ten of Swords: Catastrophizing from a single painful event
card_meanings.Five of Cups: Focusing on spilled cups, ignoring the two still standing

therapeutic_prompts: How many times has this actually happened?
What are the exceptions to this pattern?
Is this a universal truth or one data point?
reframing_questions: If this happened once, what percentage of the time does it NOT happen?
What's a counter-example from your own experience?
How would a scientist evaluate this claim?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Keep a log this week: track how often your feared outcome actually happens vs. doesn't happen

cognitive_distortions.name: Mental Filter
cognitive_distortions.definition: Focusing exclusively on negative details while filtering out positive ones
cognitive_distortions.example: Got 9/10 positive reviews but obsessing over the 1 negative

card_meanings.Nine of Swords: Ruminating on worries while ignoring solutions
card_meanings.Five of Cups: Literally focusing on spilled cups, missing upright ones

therapeutic_prompts: What positive details am I filtering out?
If I had to find 3 good things about this situation, what would they be?
Am I wearing 'gray-tinted glasses'?
reframing_questions: What would a balanced view include?
If someone else described this situation, what positives might they mention?
What am I taking for granted as 'neutral' that's actually positive?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Daily '3 Good Things' journal: write down 3 positive events each day for a week

cognitive_distortions.name: Disqualifying the Positive
cognitive_distortions.definition: Rejecting positive experiences as 'not counting' for arbitrary reasons
cognitive_distortions.example: I only succeeded because the task was easy / I got lucky

card_meanings.Four of Cups: Offered a gift, rejecting it as inadequate
card_meanings.The Hanged Man: Stuck perspective, unable to see value
card_meanings.Six of Swords: Moving away from positivity, toward familiar negativity

therapeutic_prompts: What would it mean if I DID accept this positive?
Why is it so important to dismiss my successes?
Would I dismiss this if it happened to a friend?
reframing_questions: Even if it was 'easy,' did I still do it?
If luck played a role, did I also create the opportunity for luck?
What skills did I use, even in an 'easy' situation?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Accept ONE compliment this week without deflecting or explaining it away

cognitive_distortions.name: Catastrophizing
cognitive_distortions.definition: Expecting the worst possible outcome without evidence
cognitive_distortions.example: If I make one mistake, I'll get fired and become homeless

card_meanings.The Tower: Imagining complete disaster from a small crack

therapeutic_prompts: What's the MOST LIKELY outcome, not the worst?
Have I survived similar 'catastrophes' before?
What's my evidence for this prediction?
reframing_questions: On a scale of 1-10, how bad would this realistically be?
What resources do I have to handle this if it happens?
What would I tell an anxious friend imagining this scenario?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Write down your feared catastrophe. In one week, check: did it happen? How did you cope?

cognitive_distortions.name: Emotional Reasoning
cognitive_distortions.definition: Believing that negative feelings reflect reality: 'I feel it, therefore it must be true'
cognitive_distortions.example: I feel stupid, therefore I AM stupid

card_meanings.The Moon: Emotions creating illusions, feelings obscuring facts
card_meanings.Queen of Cups: Deep emotional waters mistaken for objective truth
card_meanings.Eight of Cups: Walking away based on feeling, not facts

therapeutic_prompts: What do I FEEL vs. what do I KNOW?
If feelings aren't facts, what IS the evidence?
Have my feelings been wrong before?
reframing_questions: When I'm calm, do I believe this?
What would objective data say about this situation?
How might I feel about this tomorrow? Next week?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Fact-check ONE emotion-based belief this week: gather actual evidence pro/con

cognitive_distortions.name: Should Statements
cognitive_distortions.definition: Using rigid 'should,' 'must,' or 'ought' statements that create guilt and pressure
cognitive_distortions.example: I should always be productive / I must never make mistakes

card_meanings.Judgement: Critical evaluation based on impossible ideals

therapeutic_prompts: Where did this 'should' come from? Is it truly mine?
What would happen if I replaced 'should' with 'could' or 'prefer'?
Am I applying standards to myself I wouldn't apply to others?
reframing_questions: What do I VALUE vs. what do I think I SHOULD do?
Is this rule helping me or hurting me?
What would be more realistic or compassionate language?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Notice 'shoulds' this week. Reframe 3 of them using 'I'd like to' or 'I prefer'

cognitive_distortions.name: Labeling
cognitive_distortions.definition: Assigning global, negative labels to yourself or others
cognitive_distortions.example: I'm a loser / They're an idiot
therapeutic_prompts: Am I describing a behavior or attacking my character?
Would I use this label on someone I love?
What's a more specific, less global description?
reframing_questions: Instead of 'I AM a failure,' can I say 'I EXPERIENCED a failure'?
What qualities do I have that contradict this label?
If I had to describe the situation without labels, what would I say?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Catch ONE self-label this week and challenge it with specific evidence to the contrary

cognitive_distortions.name: Personalization
cognitive_distortions.definition: Believing you're responsible for events outside your control
cognitive_distortions.example: My friend is upset, it must be my fault

card_meanings.Four of Swords: Exhaustion from taking on others' emotions
card_meanings.The Hermit: Isolation from feeling responsible for everything

therapeutic_prompts: What percentage of this situation is actually under my control?
What OTHER factors might be contributing?
Am I taking credit for things beyond my influence?
reframing_questions: If I had no involvement, what would the outcome be?
What's HER/HIS responsibility vs. mine?
Am I powerful enough to control others' feelings/outcomes?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: List 3 factors contributing to a situation you personalized. What percentage is your actual responsibility?

cognitive_distortions.name: Mind Reading
cognitive_distortions.definition: Assuming you know what others are thinking without evidence
cognitive_distortions.example: They think I'm incompetent (with no actual statement from them)

card_meanings.Two of Swords: Blocked communication, assumptions fill the gap

therapeutic_prompts: What ACTUAL evidence do I have for this belief?
Have I asked them directly?
Could there be alternative explanations?
reframing_questions: If I asked them directly, what might they actually say?
Am I projecting my own self-criticism onto them?
What percentage certainty do I have about their thoughts?
cognitive_distortions.behavioral_activation: Test ONE mind-reading assumption by asking the person directly what they actually think

therapeutic_reading_prompts.single_card: This card reveals a thinking pattern that might be limiting you. What cognitive distortion does it suggest?

celtic_cross_positions.4_recent_past: When this pattern started or intensified
celtic_cross_positions.6_near_future: What changes if you reframe this
celtic_cross_positions.7_your_approach: Your current relationship to your thoughts
celtic_cross_positions.9_hopes_fears: What scares you about changing this pattern

achievements.name: Distortion Detective
achievements.description: Identify 10 cognitive distortions in your journal

achievements.name: Pattern Breaker
achievements.description: Catch the same distortion 5 times in a week

skill_tree_nodes.name: Identify Distortions
skill_tree_nodes.description: Learn to spot cognitive distortions in real-time

skill_tree_nodes.name: Challenge Automatic Thoughts
skill_tree_nodes.description: Question the validity of negative thoughts

skill_tree_nodes.name: Maintain Cognitive Gains
skill_tree_nodes.description: Practice prevents relapse into old patterns
